Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Novel Multidisciplinary, Multi-campus Undergraduate Minor to Enhance STEM Learning in Energy Science, Technology and Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is developing a multidisciplinary, multi-campus program minor in 'energy science, technology, and policy', through a unique regional partnership consisting of public and private four-year and two-year colleges. Project objectives include: 1) successful design and implementation of a multi-institution energy education program that is leveraging institutional academic strengths and access to student populations at the different campuses; 2) design of a program valuable for students in both technical (i.e. architecture, engineering, and science) and non-technical (i.e. business, accounting, and general studies) majors, at both two-year and four-year colleges; 3) enhancement of STEM learning through multidisciplinary curricula, experiential learning through internships and research, and incorporation of stakeholder input in course and program development; and 4) recruitment and retention of students from underrepresented and underserved populations. Third party evaluation involving peer review and an outside evaluator are used for evaluation and assessment of the project outcomes.

The project is enhancing collaboration with STEM education community and is helping to promote the two- to four-year college transition and beyond. By coordinating the program across multiple campuses, the project is facilitating articulation among institutions. Several of the schools involved have large populations of students traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, and all have significant programs aimed at recruitment and retention. The project is working to increase participation from those groups significantly.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the design and implementation of a multi-institution, multidisciplinary undergraduate academic program focused on energy science, technology and policy.  The collaborating institutional partners are all members of the Long Island Alternative Energy Consortium, a group of public and private colleges (Stony Brook University, New York Institute of Technology, Farmingdale State College, SUNY Old Westbury, SUNY Maritime and Nassau and Suffolk County Community Colleges) and Brookhaven National Laboratory dedicated to supporting energy research and workforce development through academic programs, internships and conferences to foster life-long learning.  The project also included a study of the development process itself, identifying the unique challenges of multi-institutional academic program development as well as the benefits of leveraging unique strengths and resources at different campuses.  As a result, related minors were developed at partner campuses based on a shared vision of learning outcomes including development and management of sustainable energy resources, integration of problem-based, experiential and on-line learning strategies, use of a systems-based approach to energy from a technological and policy perspective, and training which prepares students for energy technologies and an energy grid which are continuing to evolve.

Intellectual merit:  Students participating in the minors achieved significant learning gains in energy technologies, sustainability, energy resource discovery and management, global impact of energy policy, and a systems-based understanding of energy generation, transmission, storage and use.  Benefits to individual campuses included development of on-line courses, inter-institutional leveraging of educational resources, design and use of teaching technologies such as electronic portfolios and websites, and an expanded approach to recruitment of students from diverse backgrounds.  The program leveraged events which showcased undergraduate participation in internships, research and design activities, all of which served to further promote student learning opportunities.  The study also revealed challenges related to institutional concerns about curriculum design and control, transfer agreements, cross-registration, and other procedural and assessment challenges which require the sustained commitment of educators and administrators and the channeling of external industrial, economic and political driving forces to develop effective programs.

Broader impact:  The project established many new relationships with regional companies and policy-making institutions, which are continuing to provide growing opportunities for expanded student learning and workforce development.  The partnerships developed between four year public and private institutions, community colleges, and government entities have reinforced the program’s objective to recruit students from populations underrepresented in STEM fields.  This has resulted in a diverse student enrolment which includes 35% female students and 35% from underrepresented minority groups (primarily black and Hispanic).  Student enrollment also represents eight different academic majors, including engineering, natural sciences and business.  Over 75% of participants are currently or recently involved in internships or independent research programs, experiential learning opportunities which are critical to educational authenticity and engagement.
